author: arnetheduck
content: I've been trying to wrap my head around this, but compared to a http server with a socket bound to `localhost` only, what exactly are the security advantages that JWT offers for single-machine setups? The only one I can think of is that another process running on the same machine could hijack the channel _somehow_ but that seems .. far fetched (if you don't control localhost, you have serious issues already, and few of them would be mitigated by a clear-text _file_)

author: nishant0
content: JWT has no advantages for single machine setups, at least for us if users are running on the same machine and are running with an IPC compatible execution client, we just push users to use that instead.

author: ryanleeschneider
content: IIRC there was concern that enabling/disabling JWT based on if the engine API was served on localhost or not was too complicated so it was decided to just always require JWT to keep the interfaces more consistent.
